titleStmt.title: A manifesto from His Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, and the army under his command; concerning the XI. members impeached, in the name of themselves, and the kingdome of England. With seven propositions for the present peace, and settlement of the kingdome; which being granted, they assure the Parliament to draw backe. Presented, to the commissioners at Uxbridge June 27. to be by them humbly presented to the Parliament. June, 27. 1647. By the appointment of His Excellencie Sir T. Fairfax and the Councel of Warre. Signed, John Rushworth, Secr.
titleStmt.author: England and Wales. Army. Council.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A MANIFESTO From His Excellency Sir THOMAS FAIRFAX, AND The ARMY under his command; concerning the XI Members impeached, in the name of them≈øelves, and the Kingdome of England.
WITH Seven Propo≈øitions for the pre≈øent peace, and ≈øettlement of the Kingdome; which being granted, they a≈ø≈øure the Parliament to draw backe.
PRESENTED, To the COMMISSIONERS at UXBRIDGE June 27. to be by them humbly pre≈øented to the PARLIAMENT.

body.p: BY the appointment of His Excellencie Sir T. FAIRFAX and the Councel of Warre.

div.p: CAMBRIDGE, Printed for Benjamin Ridley, for the u≈øe of the Army, under his Excellencie Sir Thomas Fairfax, Anno Dom. 1647.

div.head: A MANIFESTO From his Excellency Sir Thomas, Fairfax and the Army under his Command, &c.
div.p: VVHereas the Right Honourable Commi≈ø≈øioners of Parliament have de≈øired to know from us, what things we do de≈øire to be granted, before our drawing back the Quarters of the Army to a further di≈øtance from London, upon the granting whereof we will ingage to draw back. We do in an≈øwered thereunto humbly propo≈øe the≈øe particulars following, as what are of pre≈øent nece≈ø≈øity to us, and we do de≈øire at pre≈øent to be granted, in order to the Armies, and Kingdomes pre≈øent ≈øafety, in the further debate, tran≈øaction, and ≈øettlement of tho≈øe other things contained in our former repre≈øentations, and Papers, which will require, and may admit more time; Vpon the granting of which things we ≈øhall willingly draw back (as is de≈øired) to have tho≈øe other matters debated and tran≈øacted at a further di≈øtance, with deliberation an≈øwerable to the nature and weight of them.

div.head: I.
div.p: That the Parliament would be plea≈øed to recall the Declaration inviting men to de≈øert the Army, and promi≈øing their Arriers in ca≈øe they do ≈øo, and to declare for future, that whoever ≈øhall de≈øert their Cullors or charges in the Army, without the Generalls particular licence, and di≈øe ‚Ä¢ arge, ≈øhall not have any of their Arriers payd them.

div.head: II.
div.p: That the Army may be payd up, equally to tho≈øe that have de≈øerted it: This we de≈øire may be immediately granted, or re≈øolved before we draw back, and to be performed (at lea≈øt) to the private Souldiers fully, and ≈øin part, to the Officers withall ≈øpeede convenient.

div.head: III.
div.p: That tho≈øe that have de≈øerted the Army may be in≈øtantly di≈øcharged, and di≈øper≈øed, and receive no more of their Arriers, till the Army be fir≈øt ≈øatisfied.

div.head: IV.
div.p: That both Parliament and City, may be ≈øpeedily and effectually freed, from the multitude of reformad ‚Ä¢ es, and other Souldiers before mentioned, that flock together in, or about London, by a ≈øpeedy di≈øpatch and di≈øcharging of them from the City.

div.head: V.
div.p: That all ≈øuch li≈øtings and rai≈øings of new forces or drawing together of any (as in our Remon≈øtrance & all our papers are expre≈øt) and all preparations towards a new warre, may be effectually declared again≈øt, and ≈øuppre≈øt; as al≈øo all invitations & endeavours to draw in forraigne forces, either from Scotland or other forraigne parts.

div.head: VI.
div.p:
That the continuation of the Army in the pay of the State for ≈øome competent time, (while the matter in debate relating both to the Army and Kingdome, may be concluded and ≈øetled) be at pre≈øent ordered and declared for, (before our drawing back) and the ≈øame with all ≈øpeed to be effectually put into one e≈øtabli≈øhed way, that the Army
may be enabled to pay Quatters for the ea≈øe of the countrey where it mu≈øt lie, and the Souldiery the better kept from abu≈øe to the Countrey, and reduced to that good order and di≈øcipline, which hath formerly been happily kept in this Army, though of late, (through want of pay, and other ju≈øtdi≈øcon ‚Ä¢ ents which the late provocations put upon them,) unhapilie interrupted:

div.head: VII.
div.p: That during the ≈øame ≈øpace the Parliament would re≈øolve not to propo≈øe any place for His Maje≈øties re≈øidence nearer to London then they will allow the quarters of the Army to be.

p.hi: NOw for our former de≈øire of pre≈øent ≈øu≈øpending the impeached Members from ≈øitting in the Hou≈øe.

div.p: I. Whereas we under≈øtand the Hou≈øe hath voted, that it doth not appeare that any thing hath been ≈øayd or done by them within the Hou≈øe touching any Matter contained in the Papers from the Army, for which the Hou≈øe can in Ju≈øtice ≈øu≈øpend them, though (if way were given, and opened without breach of priviledge for us to charge them with, and for others to be examined freely to te≈øtifie unto ≈øuch things,) we ≈øhould not doubt to make ≈øuch proceedings and practices of theirs in the Hou≈øe to appear, for which according to former Pre≈øidents, they ju≈øtly might and ought to be ≈øu≈øpended; yet wee are ≈øo tender of priviledges of Parliament, as that we ≈øhall at pre≈øent forbeare, to reply or pre≈ø≈øe further upon that point for the hou≈øes proceedings therein, upon their own cognizance.

2. Whereas the hou≈øe of Commons hath voted, that by the Lawes of the Land, no Judgment can bee given to ≈øu≈øpend tho≈øe Members from ≈øi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ing in the hou≈øe upon the papers pre≈øented by the Army, before particulars produced,
and proofes made; though we thinke good rea≈øons may be given, and pre≈øidents found to the contrary, even in the proceedings of this Parliament, as in the ca≈øe of the Earl of Strafford the Arch-bi≈øhop of Canterbury, the L. Keeper Finch, and others: Yet we do declare, that wee have both particulars and proofes again≈øt them ready to produce; but con≈øidering that the procedings thereupon, wil probably take up much time: And the pre≈øent un≈øetled affaires of the Kingdome, in relation to the≈øe greater matters propo≈øed by us, do require a ≈øpeedy con≈øideration. We ≈øhall be willing, that tho≈øe greater and more generall matters of the Kingdome be fir≈øt con≈øidered of, & ≈øetled, before the Cen≈øure of tho≈øe Members be determined; And therefore becau≈øe they may apprehend it ≈øome prejudice to them to have their particular Charges given in, and lye upon the „Äà‚óä„Äâ long undetermided, we ≈øhal b ‚Ä¢ e willing to forbea ‚Ä¢ the giving in of the particulars again≈øt them, till they may without interruption to the generall affaires, be immediatly proceeded upon; But if the hou≈øe doe thinke fit the particulars again≈øt them bee fir≈øt delivered in, we ≈øhall be ready to do it.

3. Whereas we under≈øtand, that the Members charged have de≈øired leave from the hou≈øes to withdraw them≈øelves: We cannot but take notice of the mode≈øty thereof, ≈øo farre, as that we are contented therewith for the pre≈øent more quiet proceeding to ≈øettle the perplexed affairs of the Kingdome (which without any private animo≈øities again≈øt per≈øons) is our greate≈øt end in what we doe; only wee declare, that (as wee ≈øuppo≈øe the Gentlemen them≈øelves from the ≈øame grounds that induced them to offer this, will ≈øtill forbear to offer the contra ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , till the matters concerning them be heard and determined, or to make any new interruption or di≈øturbance to the proceeding upon, or ≈øetlement of the generall „Äà‚óä„Äâ of the Kingdom. So we hope and ≈øhall confidently expect that the wi≈ødome and ju≈øtice of the hou≈øe, will not „Äà‚óä„Äâ any
thing to the contrary, or leave, it to an hazard thereof ‚Ä¢ ut will u≈øe ≈øufficient care and caution, again≈øt ≈øuch things, & for the bringing of tho≈øe Members to tryall, when the Hou≈øe ≈øhall judge it more ≈øea≈øonable and ≈øafe, as before expre≈øt.

closer.signed: By the appointment of His Excellency, Sir THOMAS FAIRFAX, and His COUNCEL OF WARRE. Signed, JOHN RUSHWORTH, Secr.

div.p:
WHereas without Order from the Genenerall, or the Councel of War, Nicholas Cowley Commi≈øsary Generall of provi≈øions, hath i≈ø≈øued out Warrants to ≈øome Hundreds within le≈ø≈øe then a mile of London, to bring provi≈øions from thence into
the Army, which hee pretended to be Randevouzed between London and Uxbridge; Whereas there was no ≈øuch thing ordered either by the General, or his Councel of war. It is therefore this day ordered by the Generall and his Councel of warre, that the ≈øaid Commi≈øsary Cowly ≈øhal ≈øtand committed, and he is hereby committed to the Mar≈øhal, from whence he is not to be di≈øcharged, untill he hath given ≈øatisfaction to the Commi≈øsioners for the city of London re≈øiding at Uxbridge.

closer.signed: By the appointment of his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, and the Councel of Warre. Signed John Ru≈øhworth, Secr.
